title: Stackoverflow Crash
body:
**Elasticsearch version**: 6.5.4

**Plugins installed**: []

**JVM version**:
OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_191-8u191-b12-0ubuntu0.16.04.1-b12)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.191-b12, mixed mode)

**OS version**:
Linux name 4.4.0-138-generic #⁠164-Ubuntu SMP Tue Oct 2 17:16:02 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

**Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior**:

The elasticsearch service crashed, the logs indicate stackoverflow

**Steps to reproduce**:

The elasticsearch is used with kibana, not sure what query caused it. I looked at the kibana logs, didn't see any noticable query.

**Provide logs (if relevant)**:

Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior:

The elasticsearch service crashed, the logs indicate stackoverflow

Steps to reproduce:

The elasticsearch is used with kibana, not sure what query caused it. I looked at the kibana logs, didn't see any noticable query.

Linux name 4.4.0-138-generic #⁠164-Ubuntu SMP Tue Oct 2 17:16:02 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Description of the problem including expected versus actual behavior:
The elasticsearch service crashed, the logs indicate stackoverflow
Steps to reproduce:
The elasticsearch is used with kibana, not sure what query caused it. I looked at the kibana logs, didn't see any noticable query.

node.body: This is caused by a regex query that is too complex (related to issues like https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/28344). I suggest you lower the soft limit on the maximum length of a regex query by lowering the index setting [`index.max_regex_length`](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/6.5/index-modules.html#dynamic-index-settings) from its default value of 1000 (characters). This will make the respective query fail early instead of causing problems on the server-side. The specific failure should then point you to the query and allow you to fix it.
node.bodyText: This is caused by a regex query that is too complex (related to issues like #28344). I suggest you lower the soft limit on the maximum length of a regex query by lowering the index setting index.max_regex_length from its default value of 1000 (characters). This will make the respective query fail early instead of causing problems on the server-side. The specific failure should then point you to the query and allow you to fix it.

I suggest you lower the soft limit on the maximum length of a regex query by lowering the index setting index.max_regex_length from its default value of 1000 (characters). This will make the respective query fail early instead of causing problems on the server-side. The specific failure should then point you to the query and allow you to fix it.

bodyParsed.sent: This is caused by a regex query that is too complex (related to issues like #28344).
I suggest you lower the soft limit on the maximum length of a regex query by lowering the index setting index.max_regex_length from its default value of 1000 (characters).
This will make the respective query fail early instead of causing problems on the server-side.
The specific failure should then point you to the query and allow you to fix it.

node.body:
Hey @danielmitterdorfer,
Can you instruct how to change this setting? is is possible through cluster settings API? Or should I write it in elasticsearch.yml and restart each node in the cluster?

Thanks,
Lior

bodyParsed.sent: Can you instruct how to change this setting?
is is possible through cluster settings API?
Or should I write it in elasticsearch.yml and restart each node in the cluster?

node.body: Please ask question in the future in the forum on Discuss instead of closed issues. If you follow the doc link you'll see that this is a dynamic **index** setting (**not** a cluster setting) so you can change this via the index settings API.

node.bodyHTML: Please ask question in the future in the forum on Discuss instead of closed issues. If you follow the doc link you'll see that this is a dynamic index setting (not a cluster setting) so you can change this via the index settings API.

If you follow the doc link you'll see that this is a dynamic index setting (not a cluster setting) so you can change this via the index settings API.

node.body:
Hey again @danielmitterdorfer ,
Thank you for the response, next time I will open a new issue for this case.
I do have a last question though - if this is an index setting, that means that I need to run:
1. PUT /_settings (to apply on all indices) 
2. Include this setting in all of my templates?

Thanks again,
Lior
